body: Could you retry with `deeplabcut.triangulate(config_path3d, video_path, videotype='avi', filterpredictions=True)` and let me know if this changes anything?

Thank you for your reply.
No, I got the same error as well.
![2e](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179020138-f0c263b3-7076-478c-af35-57e00d05d6e7.jpg)

That undistortion image is not good - unless you are using a panoramic camera. The board might be too small in the image, so it found a local minima that allowed it to undistort the board at the cost of dramatically warping the rest of the image. You should see something that looks like the original, but bent just a little bit so that all the lines in the board are straight.

Thank you for your reply.
I did calibration one more time with bigger board-the paper size is A3 . My camera is ZED 2 and it is not panoramic. I set the alpha 3 and the the undistortion images are better (the bent is less) 

![undistorted_points](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179293478-6495ed30-4338-4568-afba-0233ca354d06.png)

but I got the error regarding to undistorting.
![thumbnail_image_50406401](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179293649-27b54271-310d-4cde-83f8-39295654c9ba.jpg)

1. Try setting alpha to 1. That will get rid of the panoramic effect where the image repeats as it wraps, and will leave some of the black residual on the edges - i.e., you will see all of the original pixels on the edges.
2.  You set cbrow=8 and cbcol=6 (8 rows, 6 columns). i.e. you need to hold the board vertically (in "portrait" mode, not "landscape"), that probably explains the poor undistortion in your original post, and the better output in the last post.
3. That last index error means it's not finding the data files output for the videos you are passing, which is odd given that it sees that they are analyzed. Can you try running with filtering (`deeplabcut.triangulate(config,..., filterpredictions=True)`). There may be a missing `dataname.append` call in the code without filtering (below line [Line 311](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/10ef6ef2a728afd134e6e32af12df06040eebc01/deeplabcut/pose_estimation_3d/triangulation.py#L311)). That's one for @jeylau to confirm.

I did with alpha=1 but the pictures have the panoramic effect in undistortion folder:
![left-06_undistort](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179312518-2d02d87d-4aac-48e9-b7f4-17b09e5215f2.jpg)




but when I set the alpha =0 ,the pictures does not have the panormaic effects;
![left-06_undistort](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179311867-22edfe6f-7b23-4e81-9b9f-a98953557c4a.jpg)

I consider alpha=1 and filterpredictions=True, also I got pictures in portrait again, now the results:



![IMG_2453](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179312390-e8488330-d9c5-4464-be5e-9eb68bb566b6.jpg)



This is my folder where my videos are 

![IMG_2455](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/101594016/179313374-5e5ef6f1-12fa-43ca-b37e-ca6beea596fd.jpg)


In alpha =0 and alpha =1 , the error is the same.
did you rename your cameras in the 3d config.yaml file?

Hello,
Yes, in my config file , the name of cameras are left and right and the video files are output-left.avi and output-right.avi. 
and the name of pictures for calibration are left-01.jpg, right-01, etc.
can you paste here the video_path ? the error is suggesting it's not in [ ]
as at the top you use linux, and now you use Windows, and there are some clear path issues going on here :)

I tried many times in windows and linux. For example in last photo , I used this video path:
video_path= '/Users/msiam/video3d'
deeplabcut.triangulate(config_path3d, video_path, videotype='avi', filterpredictions=True)

I did not use this format for addressing video_path: deeplabcut.triangulate(config,[['/data/project1/videos/video1-camera-1.avi','/data/project1/videos/video1-camera-2.avi'],['/data/project1/videos/video2-camera-1.avi','/data/project1/videos/video2-camera-2.avi']]) 
Should I use []?


I tried both linux and windows but I got the same error in both of them. When I used windows I modified the address  in config files , ...
Thank you for your time.

I think I am not understanding the issue fully; in the very last image you post, you have the 3D file... output-3D.h5; that is the expected output of DLC-3D; your first issue had the path differently, so hard to track down what is happening on the other computer that isn't work. But, the data is there... is there something wrong with the .h5?

Yes, you are right. As the error on Linux and windows was the same and I shared here both results but on both of them I had changed the path correctly. The problem is that when I used deeplabcut.triangulate , I got the error : IndexError: list index out of range, as you see, while I got h5 too. My problem is with the coordination of output_DLC_3D.h5 , In pixel position for body part "ch" , I have the good accuracy and the right trend, but when I get 3d xyz coordination the trend is not right, also both y and z are negative. I don't know this problem is related to the Index error that I received in deeplabcut.triangulate or related to my camera calibration.

the coordinates are arbitrary; you can plot then edit as you like; but given you are getting the 3D, I don't see the issue // the issue is saying ti does not find more video pairs, but you seem to have only 1 pair and it runs :D

Thank you so much for your reply.
How can I found the origin and axis direction in 3D? I need them for translation and rotation to another origin.
easiest way is to look at pixel values in images and map them to real-space; the 3D is arbitrary sizing.
